title: A Day in the Life of Emma with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
clinical_history: Emma is a 32-year-old lawyer who has been living with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) for the past 5 years. Emma reports increased fatigue, joint pain, and a characteristic butterfly rash on her face, mainly exacerbated over the past 3/52 due to increased workload and stress. Emma first noted symptoms such as mild joint pain and occasional fevers, which over time progressed to include severe fatigue, noticeable hair loss, and a photosensitive rash. Currently, she struggles most with pain and stiffness in her hands (P1) and knees (P2), exacerbated by her sedentary work environment and long hours at the computer.

nprs.affected_area: hands - stiffness and pain primarily in the morning and after prolonged typing
knees - aching pain and intermittent swelling

aggrevating_factors: extended periods of typing, lack of sleep, stress, exposure to sunlight, cold weather
easing_factors: temperature-controlled environment, short frequent breaks, use of wrist braces, warm compresses on knees
medical_history: diagnosed with SLE at age 27 after initial presentation of fever, joint pain, and a facial rash. Regular menstrual cycle. No history of significant trauma.
medications: Hydroxychloroquine 200mg daily, Prednisone 10mg daily, Vitamin D supplements, NSAIDs as needed for joint pain
personal_history: single and lives alone in a small apartment. Emma maintains a busy professional life with frequent work commitments stretching late into the evening. Socially active, Emma enjoys attending fitness classes but has recently cut back due to worsening symptoms.
imaging: not indicated as per recent consultations, but routine blood work to monitor disease activity
